author: hikariws
content: I see rollups and other L2 solutions better than traditional centralized off-chain services. But I still don't like the idea of being on a decentralized network and having to move my funds or having my "NFTs" on a "semi-off-chain" centralized environment. It looks like decentralization is reaching its limit and failing and we're needing to move back to centralized services. If all services would go to (a variety of kinds of semi-) centralized environments, then decentralization would become more as a sort of marketing pretty word. As if we'd have an open source kernel but everything else on the OS is proprietary software and we're unable to use the OS without them.

author: treyzania

author: hikariws
content:
It's not exactly an argument, it's the impression I see, I might be wrong. It's not that L2 must be centralized, it's that I see most of them being centralized.

But I don't like at all the argument that centralization is temporary and there's work to improve it. That's what I said about BTC and ETH, they didn't start centralized and were improved later. So, if a system is centralized and claims to be being improved to be more decentralized, then there's some serious issue around.

Of course we're having pressure for both better tps and lower network fee. That's what I said, we may be facing the limits of decentralized blockchain networks and going on the path back to centralized environments. L2 systems being in practice centralized and some of them claiming it's gonna be improved later is another sign of that, that we're unable to properly scale decentralized networks and will rely back on centralized environments.
